S5.T1.1.1.caption: Correlation between   and  .
S5.T1.1.1.table:
Correlation Coefficient Pearson Spearman Kendall’s τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ
Value 0.82 0.84 0.65
references: To validate whether the confidence-based policy is precisely optimized at each state, we examine the relationship between estimated confidence ciâ¢jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—c_{ij}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the probability of the correct token yisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–y_{i}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the prediction, denoted as piâ¢jcsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—p^{c}_{ij}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Specifically, we employ SM2 to decode the validation set in a teacher-forcing manner, calculating the ciâ¢jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—c_{ij}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and piâ¢jcsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—p^{c}_{ij}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all possible states. Subsequently, a correlation analysis is performed between ciâ¢jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—c_{ij}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and piâ¢jcsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—p^{c}_{ij}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The results in Table 1 demonstrate a strong correlation, evidenced by high values in Pearson (0.82) and Spearman (0.84) coefficients, with a slightly moderate but significant Kendallâ€™s Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ coefficient (0.65). These results suggest a robust linear and monotonic relationship between ciâ¢jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—c_{ij}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and piâ¢jcsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—p^{c}_{ij}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, indicating the capacity of ciâ¢jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—c_{ij}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to accurately assess the credibility of the current predicted token. Consequently, this confirms the effectiveness of the confidence-based policy in making precise decisions at each state.

S5.T2.3.caption: The OMT performance of different OMT models before/after fine-tuning according to SM .
S5.T2.3.table:
SacreBLEU
OMT model Parameters before FT after FT
Transformer-small 47.9M 30.86 31.33
Transformer-base 60.5M 31.93 31.87
Transformer-big 209.1M 32.99 32.75
references: Additionally, we further explore the effect of the OMT modelsâ€™ translation abilities on the corresponding SiMT abilities after fine-tuning. We conduct the full-parameter fine-tuning on OMT models with Transformer-small, Transformer-base, and Transformer-big respectively. The OMT and SiMT capabilities of these models are illustrated in Table 2 and Figure 7(b), which reveal that models with stronger OMT abilities achieve better SiMT performance after fine-tuning. Besides, the results in Table 2 show that these modelsâ€™ original OMT abilities are not hurt, indicating that SM2 enables models to support both OMT and SiMT abilities.

references: Effect of â„’oâ¢mâ¢tsubscriptâ„’ğ‘œğ‘šğ‘¡\mathcal{L}_{omt}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_m italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT As shown in Figure 8, the SiMT model without â„’oâ¢mâ¢tsubscriptâ„’ğ‘œğ‘šğ‘¡\mathcal{L}_{omt}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_m italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT drops quickly. We argue this is because training without â„’oâ¢mâ¢tsubscriptâ„’ğ‘œğ‘šğ‘¡\mathcal{L}_{omt}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_m italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT may cause a worse modification. The results in Table 3 show that the OMT performance of SM2 trained without â„’oâ¢mâ¢tsubscriptâ„’ğ‘œğ‘šğ‘¡\mathcal{L}_{omt}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_m italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is significantly affected, even worse than its SiMT performance in the high latency levels. This poor OMT ability cannot provide accurate modification, thus disrupting the policy learning process.

Hyper-parameter
encoder layers 6

weight decay 0.0001
label-smoothing 0.1
max tokens 8192

(2020b) to use greedy search during inference for all baselines. The values of Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ we used are 0.3,0.4,0.5,0.55,0.6,0.65 for Zhâ†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’En, 0.3,0.4,0.5,0.55,0.6,0.65,0.7 for Deâ†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’En, and 0.3,0.4,0.5,0.6,0.65,0.7,0.75 for Enâ†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’Ro.

A6.T9.1.caption: Statistics on the average sentence length and number of sentences for LONG and SHORT groups.
A6.T9.1.table:
LONG SHORT
Average Sentence Length 36.95 14.07
Number of Sentences 1085 1084
references: To validate the robustness of SM2 to Sentence Length, we conduct additional experiments on Deâ†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’En SiMT tasks. Specifically, we divide the test set into two groups based on sentence length: LONG group and SHORT group. The average lengths and the number of sentences in each group are shown in Table 9. Then, we test SM2-Bi and SM2-Uni separately on these two groups. The translation quality under different latency levels for SM2-Bi and SM2-Uni are presented in Figure 12. For clearer comparison, we also provide the performances of OMT models (OMT-Bi, OMT-Uni) on LONG and SHORT groups.
